Start by drawing a square grid of 15 by: Comienza dibujando una cuadrícula de 15 por 15 líneas. Dos jugadores se turnan para colocar una ficha en cualquier punto donde se crucen las líneas. El jugador que consigue colocar cinco de sus fichas en línea recta, vertical, horizontal o diagonal, gana.
This game is traditionally played with b: Este juego tradicionalmente se juega con fichas negras y blancas, pero puedes usar cualquier ficha diferente o pequeños pedazos de papel. También puedes dibujar la cuadrícula con lapicera y luego usar un lápiz para marcar "x" o "o" para cada jugador; así, al terminar el juego, los puedes borrar y volver a usar la cuadrícula nuevamente.
It is very important to be watching your: It is very important to be watching your opponents moves as well as trying to make a line of 5 yourself. If your opponent has three in a row with nothing at either end - this is called "open 3" - then it is a good idea to use your turn to block one end. If they manage to get "open 4" you have certainly lost! A good attacking strategy might be to aim for two overlapping lines of open 3s - like a cross - so that it is very hard for your opponent to defend.
There is a World Championship tournament: There is a World Championship tournament for Gomuku. Since 2009 it has used the Swap 2 rule to make it a fair game, no matter who starts. There are also championships for computers to play at Gomuku! So people write an artificial intelligence program and their program plays against someone else's program to see who wins. There are also computer vs. human competitions - in 2017 a computer called Yixin beat the world champion human player Rudolf Dupszki 2-0.
For advanced players, the first player h: For advanced players, the first player has a big advantage. This advantage can be removed by starting the game using the "Swap 2" rule. Let's say at the start of the game player one is crosses (x) and player two is circles (o).
Player one begins the game by marking 3: Player one begins the game by marking 3 intersections (two with x, and one with o), player two then chooses one of these three options (i) they take crosses, ending their turn (player one becomes circles and it is now their go), (ii) they stay as circles and add one circle as normal, (iii) they add two circles to the board, but then player one now gets to decide whether they want to steal circles. After this, play as normal.
